conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks the light from the source, creating a dark area where the light cannot reach.
The size and position of a shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
When the light source moves backward, it increases the distance between the light source and the objects, affecting both the size and the position of the shadows.
As the light source moves backward, the angle at which the light rays hit the objects becomes less steep, causing the shadows to move closer to the objects.
With the light source farther away, the light rays become more parallel, resulting in smaller shadows.
Shadow A: The shadow of the sandal will move closer to the sandal and become smaller.
Shadow B: The shadow of the black box will move closer to the box and become smaller.
Shadow C: The shadow of the cake will move closer to the cake and become smaller.
Shadow D: The shadow of the twisted object will move closer to the object and become smaller.
When the light source moves backward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will all move closer to their respective objects and become smaller in size.
